messageBody:
Hi,

(I have not examined nor found any texts regarding the proposed
keyboard mapping not the unicode submission. So the following may not
be appropiate.)

I am curious about the keyboard mapping and related matters. Since
there are twice as many symbols in QS as in Orthodox some of the
assingments will seem arbitrary. So it would be a good idea to get
some mileage out it.

To me an ideal keyboard mapping would put as many of the of the very
common symbols on the querty home row. Those which are merely common
on other rows (above and below home row) accessible without modifier
keys. Those which are less common would be accessible by the shift key
(or whatever). In addition, some balance between the left and right
end of the keyboard would be nice also.

Since K. Read did not impose an official order on the characters,
other than for convenience of referral in his manuscript, it would
seem to me a great opportunity to create one that had some nice
properties.

A property of an ideal lexicographic order is that the order
correspond with the usage frequency of the symbol in written english
texts. Thus, the first symbol would be the most common. For example,
in Orthodox the lexicographic order would be
e-t-a-o-i-n-s-h-r-d-l-u-... instead of the current situation
(a-b-c-d-e-...).

A symbol frequency analysis of many texts is necessary for these two
ideas to
be implemented.
